query: Analyze the mechanisms, strengths, and limitations of describe the influence of computational power on ai capabilities., noting origins only when explicitly stated.
query_refined: Analyze the mechanisms, strengths, and limitations of describe the influence of computational power on ai capabilities., noting origins only when explicitly stated.
prompt_final_to_llm:
You are a rigorous AI researcher. Analyze mechanisms, methodologies, and implications over time. Event years may only be used if explicitly present in the snippet text. Use numeric IEEE-style citations [1], [2], etc., for statements supported by the provided snippets. Each number corresponds to one unique PDF listed below. Multiple snippets originating from the same PDF share the same number. Never assign multiple citation numbers to the same source.

**Your final answer MUST end with a separate section titled 'References'.**
This section MUST list all unique PDFs exactly once, in the following strict format:
[n] FILENAME.pdf (YEAR)

Do not fabricate author names, journals, or article titles — only use the given filename and metadata year.

Temporal Attribution Rules:
1. You may ONLY use event years that appear explicitly in the snippet text.
2. If the snippet text explicitly contains a year (e.g., 'In the 1950s', 'In 1976'), treat that as the factual historical reference.
3. If a snippet DOES NOT contain an explicit event year, you MUST NOT guess, infer, approximate, or estimate any year.
   Instead, write exactly: '(event year not stated; described in YEAR PDF [n])'.
4. The metadata publication year indicates only when the PDF was published, not when the events occurred.
5. Never replace or override an explicit event year with a metadata year.
6. Never deduce approximate historical periods from textual content (e.g., never infer '1990s' unless explicitly stated).

Output Structuring Guidelines:
- For every key historical or conceptual point:
  • If an explicit event year exists in the snippet → include it.
  • If no explicit event year exists → write '(event year not stated; described in YEAR PDF [n])'.
- Recommended dual-year structure:
  • (1950s; described in 2025 PDF [7]) The Turing Test was proposed as a benchmark.
This dual timestamping ensures full temporal grounding without hallucination.

IMPORTANT:
**Your output MUST end with a final section titled 'References'.**
This section must list all unique PDFs exactly once in IEEE numeric format.

model_output:
The mechanisms, strengths, and limitations of computational power on AI capabilities have been explored extensively over time. The Turing Test, a benchmark for assessing artificial intelligence by discerning if responses are of human or machine origin, was proposed in the 1950s [3]. Researchers generally believe that a machine passing this test can be considered intelligent [1]. Large language models (LLMs) have gained substantial interest recently due to their impressive performance. The importance of evaluating AI systems to identify current system limitations and inform the design of more powerful models has been emphasized [1]. LLMs possess the capabilities to solve diverse tasks, raising the question of whether they could be considered Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in this era [1]. Studies have shown that the performance of neural language models is related to three major factors: model size (N), dataset size (D), and training compute (C) [3]. This power-law relationship has been crucial in advancing research on LLMs [3]. The rapid technical progress of LLMs has made an important impact on the entire AI community, with the launch of ChatGPT being a notable example [3]. However, it's essential to acknowledge that while LLMs have shown remarkable capabilities for zero- and few-shot learning, their overall results should not be seen as a rigorous or meaningful benchmark in themselves [2]. To stimulate further study of few-shot learning in language models, it is crucial to understand both the strengths and limitations of these models [2]. References:
[1] 3641289.pdf (2024)
[2] 2005.14165v4.pdf (2020)
[3] 2303.18223v16.pdf (2025)
[4] 2205.01068v4.pdf (2022)
